attack_pattern.name: PZH Misidentification

obstacle.name: Loss of credentials or data
obstacle.definition: The credentials and data used by or stored on a PZP are stolen or accesed by unwanted parties

obstacle.name: PZP Enrolled in Wrong PZH
obstacle.definition: A PZP is enrolled into a PZH which the user did not intend

obstacle.name: PZP presents credentials to PZH
obstacle.definition: A PZP upon joining a PZH presents its credentials or credentials are synchronised as part of data synchronisation

obstacle.name: PZP synchronises its data with PZH
obstacle.definition: A PZP upon joining a PZH presents its credentials or credentials are synchronised as part of data synchronisation

obstacle.name: PZH Uses a Different TLS Certificate
obstacle.definition: A PZH uses a different TLS certificate from that used by the web server

obstacle.name: PZH Design allows disconnected TLS and web server certificates
obstacle.definition: A PZH is designed to allow the web server and TLS server to operate independently so that they can use different credentials

obstacle.name: Wrong Web Server Certificate
obstacle.definition: The web server uses a wrong certificate or user ignores or fails to validate the certificate

probability.rationale: Certificate validation especially on small screens is quite hard

obstacle.name: Correct URl But Wrong Underlying TLS Credentials
obstacle.definition: A PZH is accessed through the correct URL but its implementation uses different TLS credentials

obstacle.name: Incorrect PZH URL with False Credentials
obstacle.definition: The PZH URL accessed is the wrong one but the PZH presents false credentials that make it seem as though the user is accessing the correct PZH

obstacle.name: PZH Credentials Compromised
obstacle.definition: Credentials stored or used by the PZH are compromised

obstacle.name: User Visits Wrong PZH URL
obstacle.definition: A user visits the wrong PZH URL perhaps through redirection

probability.rationale: People are notoriously bad at checking the URL in the address bar

obstacle.name: User Does Not Check PZH URL
obstacle.definition: A user visits the wrong PZH URL without checking the actual address through redirection

probability.rationale: People are notoriously bad at checking the URL in the address bar

obstacle.name: PZH Presents False Credentials
obstacle.definition: A PZH presents credentials that seem to be correct to the user but are not genuine

obstacle.name: Automatically Redirected to URL
obstacle.definition: A user is automatically redirected to some URL which she did not intend to visit

obstacle.name: PZH URL too complicated
obstacle.definition: The PZH admin URL is complicated and easy to misread

obstacle.name: PZH URL displayed without prominence
obstacle.definition: The PZH admin URL bar is not visible or easy to miss

probability.rationale: People are notoriously bad at checking the URL bar

obstacle.name: Insufficiently Protected PZH Credentials
obstacle.definition: Credentials stored on the PZH are not adequately protected

attack_pattern.intent: Automatically enrol users to the wrong personal zone provider in order to capture and sell user data and credentials

motivation.description: Ethan sets up a PZH. Users are then invited through means such as phishing to enrol into the PZH. The PZH presents itself to the users as a genuine PZH with the intention that it be misidentified.

structure.exploit: Improper Validation of Host-specific Certificate Data

attack_pattern.consequences: This attack is based on a protocol flaw, and would be a vulnerability in all deployments. As a result, any webinos user could be susceptible and there could be widespread loss of data and credentials, affecting the security of personal information and privacy loss.

implementation.description: During enrolment of a PZP to a PZH, the user visits their PZH web interface to collect a short authentication token. This web interface is authenticated using standard web PKI and DNS. The enrolment process then allows the PZP to connect to the same provider and present the token. However, the PZP authentication process currently uses a different certificate (the PZH certificate not the PZH provider web interface). This is an opportunity for a man-in-the-middle attack. The same flaw may be present when a PZH is first instantiated.
